questions.text: What is the fundamental problem that the study of economics addresses? [cite: 2]
Scarcity exists because: [cite: 3]
options: People’s wants are limited, but resources are unlimited.
#Resources are limited, but people’s wants are unlimited.
Both wants and resources are unlimited.
Resources and wants are both limited to the same level.

questions.text: Which of the following best illustrates the concept of scarcity? [cite: 4]
options: A person buying a luxury car
#A city having to choose between building a new school or a park
An increase in the price of gasoline

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of efficiency? [cite: 5]
options: #Getting the maximum benefits from its scarce resources
Distributing economic prosperity uniformly among the members of society
Reducing the gap between the rich and the poor
Increasing government control over the economy

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of equality in economics? [cite: 6]
options: Maximizing the size of the economic pie
#Distributing economic prosperity uniformly among the members of society
Allowing markets to operate without intervention
Ensuring everyone has equal access to education

questions.text: Which of the following best describes rational people in economics? [cite: 7]
options: They only care about their own interests.
They make decisions based on emotions.
#They systematically and purposefully do the best they can to achieve their objectives.
They always choose the cheapest option.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes an incentive in economics? [cite: 8]
options: A law that prohibits certain behaviors
A natural disaster that disrupts production
#Something that induces a person to act
An unintended consequence of a policy

questions.text: A marginal change is one that: [cite: 9]
options: #Is a small incremental adjustment to an existing plan of action.
Leads to a total reorganization of the economy.

questions.text: Because people respond to incentives, [cite: 10]
options: Government policy can never change behavior.
#Policy makers can use incentives to influence behavior.

questions.text: According to the principle of opportunity cost, what is the cost of an economic decision? [cite: 11]
options: The monetary price paid for a good or service.
The total time spent making the decision.
#The value of the next best alternative that must be given up.
The amount of labor required to produce a good.

questions.text: Which principle suggests that people make decisions by comparing marginal benefits and marginal costs? [cite: 12]
International trade benefits a nation when: [cite: 13]
options: It only imports goods it cannot produce.
#It allows nations to specialize in what they do best.
It imposes high tariffs to protect domestic industries.

questions.text: Adam Smith’s “invisible hand” refers to: [cite: 14]
options: #The ability of free markets to reach desirable outcomes through self-interest.
The role of central planning in resource allocation.
The use of technology to improve production.

questions.text: Governments may intervene in a market economy in order to: [cite: 15]
options: Set prices for all goods and services.

questions.text: Which of the following is a positive, rather than a normative, statement? [cite: 16]
options: The government should lower taxes to stimulate the economy.
#A higher minimum wage leads to higher unemployment.
Equality is more important than efficiency.

questions.text: The following parts of government regularly rely on the advice of economists: [cite: 17]
options: Only the Council of Economic Advisers
#The Department of Treasury, the Department of Labor, and the Council of Economic Advisers

questions.text: Economists may disagree because they have different: [cite: 18]
In an hour, Mateo can wash 2 cars or mow 1 lawn, and Sophia can wash 3 cars or mow 1 lawn. Who has the absolute advantage in washing cars? [cite: 19, 20]
In an hour, Mateo can wash 2 cars or mow 1 lawn, and Sophia can wash 3 cars or mow 1 lawn. Who has the comparative advantage in mowing lawns? [cite: 21, 22]
A nation will typically import those goods in which: [cite: 23]
options: It has a higher cost of production than other nations.
Its workers are more productive than foreign workers.

questions.text: If producing an aircraft requires 10,000 labor hours in the U.S. and 20,000 in China, and producing a shirt requires 2 hours in the U.S. and 1 in China, what will these nations trade? [cite: 24]
options: #The U.S. will export aircraft, and China will export shirts.
China will export aircraft, and the U.S. will export shirts.

questions.text: Kayla cooks dinner in 30 minutes and washes laundry in 20 minutes; her roommate takes twice as long for each. How should the work be allocated? [cite: 25, 26]
options: #Kayla and the roommate should specialize based on comparative advantage.
They should share each task equally.

questions.text: When Mateo and Sophia specialize and trade based on comparative advantage, what happens? [cite: 27]
options: One person is better off and the other is worse off.
#Both can consume more than they could without trade.

questions.text: Most economists believe that tariffs are: [cite: 28]
options: #Harmful to the economy as a whole.
Necessary for a country to grow.

questions.text: What is the best definition of a market? [cite: 29]
options: A physical place where people trade.
A government agency that sets prices.
#A group of buyers and sellers of a particular good or service.
A system where only large corporations operate.

questions.text: In a perfectly competitive market, [cite: 30]
options: #There are many buyers and many sellers, and no single person can influence the price.
Only one seller provides a unique product.

questions.text: Which product best fits the definition of a perfectly competitive market? [cite: 31]
What is the primary characteristic of a market economy? [cite: 32]
options: #Allocation of resources through decentralized decisions of firms and households
A lack of private property rights

questions.text: What is an economic model? [cite: 33]
options: A detailed replica of the entire economy
#A simplified representation of reality used to understand economic relationships
A complex mathematical proof that is always true
A physical structure showing how money flows

questions.text: In the circular-flow diagram, in markets for the factors of production: [cite: 34]
options: #Households are sellers and firms are buyers.

options: The impact of a tax on the market for cigarettes.

The effect of rent control on the housing market.
#The influence of government spending on national unemployment.

options: The price of hot dogs (a substitute)

options: Direct control of the economy by a few firms

questions.text: Which good is likely to have a more inelastic demand? [cite: 44]

options: Economic profit includes only explicit costs.
#Economic profit includes both explicit and implicit costs.

questions.text: If a firm's marginal product of labor is 10, what does this mean? [cite: 46]
options: #One additional worker increases total output by 10 units.
The firm earns 10 dollars per worker.
The cost of hiring a worker is 10 dollars.

questions.text: What does diminishing marginal product of labor indicate? [cite: 47]
options: Total output decreases as more workers are hired.
#The additional output from an extra worker decreases as more workers are hired.
The cost of production is decreasing.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of perfectly competitive markets? [cite: 48]

options: #A few large firms that are interdependent
Easy entry and exit from the market

questions.text: What is a natural monopoly? [cite: 54]
options: #A monopoly that arises because a single firm can supply a good at a lower cost than two or more firms
A monopoly created by government law

questions.text: A firm in a monopolistic market faces a: [cite: 55]
Which of the following best describes the term "externality"? [cite: 56]
options: The cost of production for a firm
#The uncompensated impact of one person’s actions on the well-being of a bystander
The profit earned by a competitive firm

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a positive externality? [cite: 57]
options: #A neighbor’s well-kept garden increasing your property value
Cigarette smoke in a public place

questions.text: What does a point inside the production possibilities frontier indicate? [cite: 58]
If an economy is operating on its PPF, what does this imply? [cite: 59]
options: #It can only produce more of one good by producing less of another.

questions.text: What happens to equilibrium price and quantity when demand increases while supply remains constant? [cite: 60]
In the law of demand, what is the relationship between price and quantity demanded? [cite: 61]
When supply decreases while demand remains constant, what happens? [cite: 62]
If the cross-price elasticity between two goods is positive, what can we conclude? [cite: 63]
options: One good is an inferior good.

questions.text: What does the term "elasticity of demand" measure? [cite: 64]
options: The change in price when supply changes
#The responsiveness of quantity demanded to a change in price
The total revenue of a firm
The shift in the demand curve

questions.text: If the government imposes a price ceiling below equilibrium, what occurs? [cite: 65]

options: An increase in the price of raw materials
A decrease in the number of sellers
An increase in taxes on production

questions.text: How does demand for a luxury good change when income increases? [cite: 67]
What is the situation called when quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied? [cite: 68]

options: Change in price / Change in quantity
#Percentage change in quantity demanded / Percentage change in price

questions.text: If a good has many substitutes, what happens to its price elasticity? [cite: 70]

options: Price increases, quantity stays the same.
Price stays the same, quantity increases.

questions.text: What is the relationship between elasticity of demand and total revenue? [cite: 72]
options: If demand is elastic, a price increase raises total revenue.
#If demand is inelastic, a price increase raises total revenue.
Total revenue is always independent of elasticity.

questions.text: When the government imposes a tax, how do equilibrium price and quantity change? [cite: 73]
options: Price decreases for sellers, quantity increases.

If the price of a good increases by 10% and quantity demanded decreases by 20%, what is the elasticity? [cite: 76]

questions.text: What is the definition of fixed costs? [cite: 83]
options: Costs that change with the level of output.

options: The total monetary cost of production.

questions.text: Which market structure typically exhibits non-price competition? [cite: 95]

options: When price is below average total cost

questions.text: What does GDP stand for? [cite: 98]

options: #To get one thing, you must give up another.

questions.text: Which example demonstrates “thinking at the margin”? [cite: 104]
options: Deciding whether to go to college or work full-time.
#Deciding whether to study for one more hour for an exam.
Buying a new car instead of a used one.

questions.text: How do economists define incentives? [cite: 105]
options: Something that punishes a specific behavior.
#Something that induces a person to act, such as a reward or punishment.
A fixed rule that cannot be changed.

questions.text: What does “trade can make everyone better off” imply? [cite: 106]
options: #Nations can specialize and enjoy a greater variety of goods.
Only the richer nation benefits from trade.

questions.text: In market principles, what does a competitive market lead to? [cite: 107]

options: #Governments can improve market outcomes when externalities exist.

questions.text: Which situation represents an externality? [cite: 109]
options: A person buying a loaf of bread.
A firm hiring a new manager.

questions.text: Which statement reflects that living standards depend on production? [cite: 110]
options: Countries with high taxes have the highest living standards.

questions.text: Which principle explains inflation? [cite: 111]
options: Prices rise when the government increases taxes.

What represents the idea that markets organize economic activity well? [cite: 113]

options: Restricting trade with all other nations.
#Improving the education and skills of the workforce.

options: One country must lose for another to win.

options: #An airline selling a last-minute seat for less than the average cost.

options: Higher inflation leads to higher unemployment.

questions.text: Why do people face trade-offs? [cite: 119]
options: Because they have too much money.

options: To make their models more complex.

questions.text: Which is an example of a positive statement? [cite: 121]
options: The government should provide free healthcare.

options: #The government should increase the minimum wage.
